org.orgName: Dotation Carnegie pour la Paix Internationale
org.desc: Conducts research programs, discussions, publications on international affairs and the american foreign policy. Until 1948, it was composed of 3 divisions: Intercourse and education, Economics and history, International law.

The Senate under the French Third Republic was one of the two legislatives bodies, the second behing the Chamber of Deputies, established by the French Constitutional Laws of 1875. This is a strict bicameralism, with the same legislative powers for both chambers. Laws must be voted on under the same terms by both chambers. Only sign of precedence, the Chamber of Deputies is the first to rule on financial laws. On the other hand, the Head of State must obtain the assent of the Senate to proceed with the dissolution of the lower house. Politcally, the creation of the upper house is a compromise between a National Assembly where monarchist (divided themselves between Orleanists and Legitimists) and republicans oppose. The latter accept the presence of an assembly having a conservative trait in exchange for the rallying of the first to the Republic.
French infantry hunter unit.
One of the oldest divisions of the French army
French learned society devoted to the humanities, founded in February 1663 as one of the five academies of the Institut de France
learned society, founded in 1666 by Louis XIV at the suggestion of Jean-Baptiste Colbert, to encourage and protect the spirit of French scientific research
One of the five academies of the Institut de France; the oldest French institution covering the field of human and social sciences
Authoritative French learned body on matters pertaining to the French language; a division of "Institut de France"
French royalist movement
Formed in 1905 by Charles Jasper Glidden and Augustus Post, among others, to promote aviation in America.
Founded by Ernest Archdeacon. First aeronautical institution in the world.

Former legislative assembly in the late Russian Empire

Created in 1911 on the iniative of the Wright brothers. It was closed on the declaration of war but was quickly reopened, to train pilots to aerial combats.
French military academy founded by Napoleon in 1802.

org.orgName: Ecole de tir aérien de Cazaux
org.desc: Founded by the Captain pilot Ferdinand Marzac in 1915, the base was then used for the development of the first military pilots in the art of aerial combat.
French public higher education institution (grande école) located in Paris, rue d'Ulm
Series of agreements from 1904 between the United Kingdom and France about colonies in Africa, Siam (Thailand), Newfoundland, and New Hebrides (Vanuatu)
Full-time body at the head of the Prussian Army and German Army
Paris Law Faculty of the former University of Paris (1806-1896)
French educational institution based at the Sorbonne, set up by the imperial decree regarding the University of France on 17 March 1808.
Principal institution of scientific higher education in France

org.desc: Organization founded in 1902
Automotive brand manufacturer created by Henry Ford.
security branch of France's Gendarmerie responsible for Paris-area security and honor guards
Part of the Guards Division; Foot Guards regiment of the British Army

org.orgName: Société de l'histoire de la guerre
org.desc: In 1919, the War History Society was created with the aim of consolidating the activities of the new War Library-Museum, - which in 1934 became the Library of Contemporary International Documentation (BDIC); it constitutes itself as a "history laboratory" based on "the methods of scientific erudition". A second mission of "popular education" - or, to use a more contemporary phrase, "dissemination of research results" - is added to this primary objective.
20th-century intergovernmental organisation, predecessor to the United Nations, founded in 1920
Term under which two groups of French artists united, the first for some exhibitions in the early 1860s, the second since 1890 for annual exhibitions.

Non-profit non-governmental research institute and documentation center founded in 1907 under the name Central Office of International Associations by Henri La Fontaine, the 1913 Nobel Peace Prize laureate, and Paul Otlet, a founding father of what is now called information science.
Parisian social and dining club founded in 1917.
International organisation of national parliament, founded in 1889 by Frédéric Passy and Randal Cremer.
Patriotic society to support the policies of Abraham Lincoln
Name given to the movement of political rapprochement which united the French of all tendencies (political or religious) at the outbreak of the First World War.
Business entity in the USA incorporated under any state or territorial statute
Private research university in Cambridge, Massachusetts, United States
Former university in Paris, France from the middle ages to 1970
department of the British Government responsible for the administration of the British Army
interfaith association and NGO of Protestant Christian origin
Institution of local government in Russian Empire
French publishing house founded in 1870 by Auguste Armand Colin, specialized in publishing works concerning human sciences, economics and education

Association created by Gabriel Hanoteaux (then Minister of Foreign Affairs) to promote relations between France and the American continent as a whole.
Private French institution founded in 1894
Portuguese parliament
Federal legislature of Canada

French news agency which took advantage of the opportunities brought by the advances of the radio during the First World War.
bicameral legislature of the United States.

Association that aims to improve mediation between countries (especially between Europe and the United States).

org.orgName: Conservatoire national supérieur de musique et de danse de Paris
org.desc: Music and dance school in Paris, France.
Highest jurisdiction in the French judiciary order.

org.orgName: Compagnie des chemins de fer de Paris à Lyon et à la Méditerranée
org.desc: Former French railway company (1857–1937), replaced by SNCF.

org.orgName: Fédération française des travailleurs du livre
org.desc: Trade union representing printing workers in France, founded in 1881 at a conference in Paris. In 1895, it was one of the main founding affiliates of the General Confederation of Labour (CGT).
French administrative justice institution and legal counsel to the government.
National trade union center, founded in 1895 in the city of Limoges. It is the first of the five major French confederations of trade unions.
French political organization of the iron and steel industry.
Society formed in 1901 to promote women's rights.
Multinational nonprofit news agency.

org.orgName: Ligue des Droits de l'Homme et du Citoyen
org.desc: Human Rights NGO association to observe, defend and promulgation of Rights Man within the French Republic in all spheres of public life.
International news agency established in London in 1851 by the German-born Paul Reuter.
Leading press agency in Italy from the mid-19th century until the end of World War II, and founded by Guglielmo Stefani on 26 January 1853 in Turin.

Formed by the meeting, in 1905, of the French Anti-Alcoholic Union, the French Temperance Society (created in 1872 as the French Association against the Abuse of Alcoholic Beverages, last name adopted in 1880) and the University Star.

org.orgName: Ecole des Sciences politiques de Paris
org.desc: French grande école and grand établissement located in Paris, with additional campuses in Dijon, Le Havre, Menton, Nancy, Poitiers and Reims. Sciences Po is a specialised institute for the study of social sciences, offering courses and research in political science, history, economics, law, and sociology.

Non-state American organization established in 1915 to promote the formation of an international body for world peace, formed in Philadelphia by American citizens concerned by the outbreak of World War I in Europe.

Fund established to recognize persons who perform extraordinary acts of heroism in civilian life in the United States and Canada, and to provide financial assistance for those disabled and the dependents of those killed saving or attempting to save others.
Department store in Paris.
French department store chain.
French higher education and research establishment in Paris.
